ALLEGATION: Staff allowed a resident to smoke a vape pen that contained
THC in it.
On 7/15/19, staff 1 sent an email with resident 1 drug screen. Resident 1 tested positive
for Marihuana Metabolite. Resident 1 was tested on 7/12/19.
On 7/18/19, this consultant and DHHS Social Service Worker interviewed staff 2 face to
face at the Wolverine Human Resource Building. Staff 2 reported he does have his
Medical Marihuana Card. Staff 2 reported he was in aa car accident and punctured a
lung in the accident. Staff 2 reported he takes marihuana in different ways. Staff 2
reported he eats cookies and inhales through a vape pen. Staff 2 reported that THC is
in the cookies and vape pen. Staff 2 reported his vape pen is silver and yellow. Staff 2
reported he lost his vape pen the first week he was at work at the facility. It was found
and given back to him. Staff 2 reported he does use the marihuana on his breaks at the
2

facility by inhaling with his vape pen. Staff 2 reported the marihuana in his vape pen can
cause calming effect and a high. Staff 2 reported he also uses marihuana recreationally
by smoking “joints” and “doobies”. Staff 2 reported he was asked to transport resident 1
to the emergency room. While he was transporting, resident 1 asked staff 2 if he “could
hit that” referring to vape pen on the way to the emergency room (at Frankenmuth).
Resident 1 had a headache from a possible concussion. Staff 2 reported he told
resident 1, “I don’t have it”. Staff 2 reported resident 1 then said, “come on I know you
have it.” Staff 2 then reported they went to the emergency room but then needed to go
to a different emergency room located at Saginaw Covenant (30 minutes away). On the
way there, resident 1 asked for the vape pen 2-3 times more. At the emergency room,
staff 2 reported resident 1’s parents were there and he left them alone for a few
minutes. Staff 2 reported he smoked marihuana from his vape before driving resident 1
to the emergency room. Staff 2 reported he did not give marihuana to resident 1.
On 7/18/19 this consultant and DHHS Social Service worker interviewed resident 1 face
to face at Clarence Fischer Center. Resident 1 reported staff 2 took him to the “med
express” and then had to go to hospital in Saginaw for MRI follow up. Resident 1
reported he saw staff 2’s vape pen in the charger in the vehicle and asked him if he
smoked. They discussed smoking “weed” and staff 2 puled out his cartridges. Resident
1 reported he “hit” the vape pen 4 times. Resident 1 reported he felt high afterwards.
Resident 1 reported there were three cartridges. One was named “purple crush”, the
other was “crazy train”, and the third was “banana”. Staff 2 told him they were all
“uppers”. Resident 1 reported the vape pe was green or yellow. It had a black USB cord
for a charger. Resident 1 reported staff 2 told him he was in an accident where he broke
a lot of bones and was in a lot of pain, which is why he smokes marihuana.
Resident 1 was taken to the hospital on 7/3/19 according to medical documents.
Personnel records for staff 2 was reviewed. Staff 2 had two Wolverine Counseling
forms.
The first write up was in regard to him losing his vape pen on campus. The incident
Occurred on 6/28/2019. He received a “warning”
The second write up was in regards to him using his cell phone. The incident took place
on 7/6/2019. He received a one day unpaid suspension.
All clearances were run and all training was provided.
Wolverine Polices:
Employee Code of Conduct:
WHS staff shall hold the health, safety and welfare, and the best interests of the
client as a primary guide in all decisions affecting the client.
WHS staff shall uphold legal and accepted moral codes pertaining to professional
conduct…
Wolverine Transportation of clients:
3

…smoking and the use off tabacco products is prohibited on Wolverine Human
Services property including WHS vehicles…
Substance Abuse:
Use, possession, purchase, manufacture, distribution, dispensation, trade, offer
for sale or actual sale of controlled substances, illegal drugs, or alcohol on
WHS’s premises or during the performance of WHS-related work.
Being under the influence of controlled substances, illegal drugs or alcohol on
WHS’s premises or during the performance of WHS related work. “Being under
the influence” of alcohol is defined as having any breath alcohol content; “being
under the influence” of drugs is testing positive at a specified level.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: Staff 2 did not follow the agency policies above. Staff 2 smoked
marihuana with a resident. Staff 2 smoked marihuana while
transporting a resident. Staff 2 reported he smoked marihuana
on his breaks when working and before he transported resident
1 to the hospital.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Staff qualifications.
(1) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
4

ANALYSIS: Staff 2 was provided with training, per personnel file. Staff 2 was
using substances at the facility and was using substances with
resident 1 while operating a motor vehicle.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended the license remain unchanged at this time.
